Key Arguments: The proposed legislation contravenes Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which protects freedom of opinion and expression.
The legislation would suppress freedom of expression and undermine democracy by curtailing open discussions and debates.
It poses a threat to media independence, potentially leading to government control or censorship.
The legislation would deny public access to information, impeding their right to know and participate in democratic processes.
It threatens pluralism and diversity of ideas, leading to media homogenization.
The legislation could obstruct societal progress by stifling creativity and innovation.
There is a potential for abuse of power, with authorities possibly using the legislation to suppress dissenting voices.
The legislation could create a chilling effect on journalists, leading to self-censorship.
It could impact media pluralism by concentrating media ownership and reducing diversity of voices.
Notable Quotes: The Australian Human Rights Commission has warned against giving any body the power to be ‘the sole arbiter of truth’.
It cannot be argued strongly enough that legislation that limits free speech in the media directly contradicts the principles enshrined in Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
